is a route of 26.5km (shortcuts can reduce this to 17km) passing through

. It's for hikers or cyclists, and brings you past oak wood sculptures made by the artist Ad Wouters, 2 of the oldest trees in the forest and several other attractions which are worth a visit.

Ad's Path as it's described here, was based on the description you can find on

in Dutch. The description in the present article deviates from the original though. It's also written in such a way that one can either follow the whole route in one go, or one can divide it up into shorter stretches and go and come back or jump in by using public transportation. For very adventurous people there is even the possibility to camp half way through. The camping site is very primitive though and doing that would involve a lot more preparation and dragging camping gear along.

The theme of the route revolves around the artwork of Ad Wouters, who is an artist with a social and an ecological engagement. He worked in construction, starting when he was 13. This experience gave him a lot of knowledge of materials like plaster and wood. Later on, he worked in the restoration of historic buildings. Unfortunately he fell from a church tower in a work-related accident, which left him unable to work full days. He used this misfortune as an opportunity and developed himself as a creative artist, with a preference to use recycled materials.

On this walk you'll encounter several wooden sculptures and one work made of metal wire filled with litter, as a statement about how we manage waste products. In Leuven there are more wooden sculptures, but also a statue of Saint Michael, which seems to be made of metal, but it's actually coated polyester, the material also used to make kayaks, which was then coated with bronze to reduce cost.
His motivation for creating and setting up these works in public spaces is for people to enjoy them.

created a network of numbered walking nodes all across Zuid-Dijleland (Southern Dyle River Area), which were used to give pointers about this route. Sometimes they're merely used to help indicate in which direction to get started though, or even which ways not to take. It's best to look at the included map or

and load it into a GPS device.
Since this numbered node network is mapped on Openstreetmap, it's possible to show the node numbers on the dynamic map included in this article. To do so, you need to manually switch on the

. Having the layer on all the time, clutters the map with too much information. The hiking node network is represented with orange lines. The loop of the entire 'Pad van Ad' is in purple marked with PA. The shortcuts are marked with PAB. There are however some other loops which are also in purple on that layer. The colour merely indicates the kind of route. Long distance routes, like GR, are marked in blue.
If you'd like to see where the buses travel, you can switch layers to
It's a sturdy hike, so you may prefer to go by bicycle instead. It leads you through the forests south of
. It describes a lot of interesting things to see and do in the area. Multiple shortcuts are described along the way.
If you're going to hike, it's possible to get a head start by taking bus number 1 until where it turns to the right off of Naamsesteenweg into Huttelaan

. There are buses of line 1 every 60 minutes from the station of Leuven. The service runs every day.

With bus 18 there are 2 more possibilities though. 
If you continue to

(pedestrian overpass), you can follow the route to walk back to the arboretum. This reduces the distance to 9-14km.

But if you'd consider that option, it's even better to continue one stop further (

, from where you can see the Ecoduct)

The 2 extra nearby statues certainly make this worth your while. The length of the route back to Arboretum becomes between 11 and 18km.
There is also bus line 5 (Wakkerzeel - Wijgmaal - Leuven - Haasrode - Blanden - Vaalbeek). Take it to almost the last stop

in Vaalbeek, just after crossing the express road for the second time. (This saves you 2,5km).

. This is probably mainly interesting if you already used the train to get to Leuven, Wavre, Ottignies or Louvain-la-Neuve. The stations are more distant from the route than the bus stops of line 337.

:* Right after you see a place where dogs can be unleashed, there is a way on your right which was formerly military area, but now it's like a natural reserve. This way is accessible by wheelchair. Unfortunately, there is not very much to see, except for a road 1,4km long, where all you are allowed to do is go straight on. It could be a good place to come to rest, of course.

. It's allowed to camp here, near the pole with the pump. This water is not potable though. To get good spring water you can go down toward Minnebron, 1,5 km further north from the camp site. The quality is monitored regularly.

If visiting these statues whet your appetite, you may be interested to know there are a few more. Their exact location can be found in the GPX file.

value: , in the Saint-Donatus City park of Leuven.
In the botanical garden there is the
In the Sint-Michielskerk on Naamsestraat, there is a representation of

who just broke his sword, after killing the dragon. This statue looks like it is made of messing. In fact it's made of polyester, which is painted/coated with bronze paint, then varnished, keeping the bronze colour very light since it never to the chance to oxydate.
At the entrance of the school in Haasrode there is an actual bronze statue, for which Ad created the mold. It represents a man eating a carrot, a
, which is the mockname of people living in Haasrode, which they got after having to resort to eating carrots due to a bad potato season, back when people were completely dependent on local farming.
name=Voor hen van toen (For them, for what they did back then)
image=Voor hen van toen Ad Wouters.jpg
near the bedding of the defunct (since 1950) steam tram in
in Neerijse on the border with Sint-Joris-Weert, to thank all the volunteers who helped out maintaining this sizable natural reserve over the years.

Another wood sculpture is in the works. It will go inside an elementary school for children with learning disabilities when it's finished though. So it will be somewhat less accessible to the public than the others.
